item.title: Old Fashioned
item.description: Some people will argue an Old Fashioned must be made with a sugar cube. Those people haven’t tried it with burnt sugar syrup. 2 oz rye whiskey¾ oz burnt sugar syrup2 dashes Angostura bitters2 dashes orange bittersorange twist Add ice to a rocks glass. Add both bitters, then the whiskey and burnt sugar syrup. The syrup will sink to the bottom, so give it a quick stir to mix.

item.title: Daiquiri
item.description: 2 oz white rum¾ oz lime juice¾ oz simple syrup Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Shake well and strain into a coupe glass.

item.title: Manhattan
item.description: 2 oz rye whiskey1 oz sweet vermouth2 dashes Angostura bitters Combine in a shaker with ice. Stir, then strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a Maraschino cherry.

item.title: Martini
item.description: Everyone has an opinion about martinis. I’ll spare you mine, and just give you my recipe. Trust me. I often use a blanc vermouth instead of the traditional dry, but it’s delicious with either. Any type of gin works in a martini, but I prefer a sweeter style. 2¼ oz genever gin¾ oz dry vermouth Add to cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Stir well, then strain into a martini glass.

item.title: Sidecar
item.description: The simple syrup isn’t traditional, but that’s how I learned it, and I like the touch of additional sweetness. 2 oz Cognac¾ oz orange liqueur¾ oz lemon juice¼ oz simple syruporange twist, discarded Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a coupe glass. Express the oils from an orange twist over the drink, then discard the peel.
